docs.lead_paragraph: NOW that the nominees for the 77th annual Academy Awards have been announced, it is time to consider a category that also deserves its due: best product in a leading role. Last year provided a bumper crop of nominees for the make-believe category, reflecting the increasing interconnectedness of Madison Avenue and Hollywood. As with the actual categories, the candidates for the fanciful best-product award have been winnowed to five nominees, all from Oscar-nominated films. Here is a look at them. AFLAC -- The familiar duck that promotes the supplemental health insurance sold by Aflac made its film debut in ''Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events,'' appearing briefly in a scene playing, well, itself. In the scene, the duck, inside a boat during a storm, is squarely in the path of an unfortunate event involving a flaming stove.

headline.main: Never mind the best-picture nominees. For the advertising-obsessed, it is time to pick the best product in a leading role.

docs.abstract: Stuart Elliott column on prominence of brands in films nominated for Academy Awards: so-called product placement; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Never mind the best-picture nominees. For the advertising-obsessed, it is time to pick the best product in a leading role.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration has touched off a furious debate with new rules allowing employers to collect billions of dollars in federal subsidies for prescription drug benefits less generous than what many retirees were expecting under the new Medicare law. In theory, those retiree benefits should be at least equal in value to the new Medicare drug benefit. But that will not always be the case, according to Medicare officials, labor unions and specialists in employee benefits.

headline.main: Employers Can Get Medicare Subsidies For Lower Benefits

docs.abstract: Bush administration touches off furious debate with new rules allowing employers to collect billions of dollars in federal subsidies for prescription drug benefits less generous than what many retirees are expecting under new Medicare law; Medicare officials, labor unions and specialists in employee benefits say that retiree benefits will not always be equal in value to new Medicare drug benefit; administration says many employers will be able to ignore Medicare's catastrophic coverage, which helps people with high drug costs and accounts for one-fourth of annual value of standard Medicare drug benefit; Dr Mark B McClellan, administrator of Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, says federal subsidies would reverse erosion of retiree health benefits and enable employers to offer high-quality retiree coverage at much lower cost; AFL-CIO health policy analyst JoAnn C Volk claims rules will allow employer to get subsidy for benefit that is less valuable to retirees than what they would receive if they signed up for Medicare drug benefit and employer dropped coverage altogether (M)
docs.snippet: New rules would allow employers to collect subsidies for drug benefits less generous than what many retirees were expecting under the new Medicare law.

docs.lead_paragraph: WAYNE CAHILLY conducts a kind of triage, and when necessary he uses a kind of EKG as well as a global positioning device. His patients are trees, but his services in Westchester are focused on humans and their property, not on tree health care. Mr. Cahilly is an arboricultural consultant under contract to the Town of Greenburgh. He assesses trees in hopes of identifying any that may tumble onto public roadways and trails -- as well as structures, swimming pools, picnic tables and ball fields where someone could be hurt or killed by a sudden uprooting or by a falling branch.

headline.main: The Doctor Is Out, Locating His Patients

docs.abstract: Article on Wayne Cahilly, arboricultural consultant under contract to Greenburgh, NY, who assesses trees in hopes of identifying any that may fall onto public roads and property; photos (M)
docs.snippet: WAYNE CAHILLY conducts a kind of triage, and when necessary he uses a kind of EKG as well as a global positioning device. His patients are trees, but his services in Westchester are focused on humans and their property, not on tree health care.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: MOST horse racing supporters in Westchester view the latest challenges to a planned $185 million lottery casino at Yonkers Raceway as just more in a series of surmountable hurdles. A legal challenge to video lottery terminals proposed for several racetracks across the state as well as state budget issues are the most recent obstacles, but the case is expected back in court in March and legislators have said they may rewrite the law in question. Supporters throughout the county -- business people, bettors, investors and horsemen among them -- hope that the prize at the end is a return of the 106-year-old track, where Seabiscuit once ran, to its former glory.

headline.main: In a Casino Plan, Hopes for Rebirth

docs.abstract: Article on plans to upgrade deteriorating clubhouse and grandstand area at Yonkers Raceway and install video lottery terminals in new casino; supporters hope changes will turn 106-year-old track around; legal challenge to video display terminals at racetracks remains; photos (M)
docs.snippet: MOST horse racing supporters in Westchester view the latest challenges to a planned $185 million lottery casino at Yonkers Raceway as just more in a series of surmountable hurdles.    A legal challenge to video lottery terminals proposed for several...

docs.lead_paragraph: UNTIL recently, a pension seemed like a sure thing. If you worked long enough, you could count on a predetermined stream of income upon retirement, backed by the federal government. Now, however, a series of pension failures at companies like United Airlines, US Airways, Bethlehem Steel, Kaiser Aluminum and Polaroid has cast doubt over such certainties. While the government insures pensions, the coverage is limited -- and it is much more varied than the government's insurance for bank deposits. In the last two years, tens of thousands of pilots, steelworkers, managers, mechanics and others have discovered that the pensions they earned were richer than the government's insurance -- something that they did not know until their pension plans had failed.

headline.main: Taking the Wheel Before a Pension Runs Into Trouble

docs.abstract: Mary Williams Walsh Planning column, in light of recent series of pension failures at large companies, offers advice on steps that can be taken to determine whether a pension fund is safe and what to do if it is going downhill; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Who stands to lose when a pension plan fails? And, just as important: If you find that you are not fully insured, what can you do?

docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone complains about the food. Nobody wants to sit with the misfits. There are leaders and followers, social butterflies and loners, goody-goodies and troublemakers. Friendships are intense and so are rivalries. Everybody knows everybody else's business. Except for the traffic jam of wheelchairs and walkers, the dining room at the Atria assisted living community here might as well be a high school cafeteria.

headline.main: LIFE, ASSISTED: No Place Like Home; Under One Roof, Aging Together Yet Alone

docs.abstract: Assisted living was hailed as dignified alternative to nursing homes when introduced in mid-1980's, yet few sociologists and public health researchers have studied social organization and daily preoccupations of these communities; experts agree this stage in life is bleaker than most Americans admit; yet leaving assisted living community, on average after two and one half years, is rarely voluntary but due to dwindling assets; nursing homes charge on average 40 percent more but also accept Medicaid; photos (L)
docs.snippet: In the past decade, the number of elderly Americans in assisted living has tripled, to nearly one million.

docs.lead_paragraph: The execution of Michael Bruce Ross, the convicted serial killer who was scheduled to be the first person put to death in Connecticut in 45 years, was delayed hours after a conference call in which a federal judge criticized his lawyer's handling of the case. The lawyer, T.R. Paulding, announced early yesterday -- little more than an hour before Mr. Ross had been scheduled to die -- that ''a question has been raised about a conflict of interest'' that touched on his continued representation of Mr. Ross.

headline.main: Conference Call With Judge Preceded Delay in Execution

docs.abstract: Execution of Michael Bruce Ross, convicted serial killer scheduled to be first person put to death in Connecticut in 45 years, is delayed hours after conference call in which Judge Robert N Chatigny criticizes handling of case by Ross's lawyer, T R Paulding; Paulding says question was raised about conflict of interest that touched on his continued representation of Ross (M)
docs.snippet: A lawyer whose statement delayed Connecticut's execution of a serial killer acted after a conference call in which a federal judge criticized his handling of the case.

byline.original: By JAMES BARRON and STACEY STOWE

docs.lead_paragraph: ''He was in love with me, and I was in love with him,'' Myrna Whitley said of her husband, Xavier Whitley. ''He was smart, he was funny; he looked a little bit like Anthony Hopkins and Jack Nicholson.'' The Whitleys dabbled in acting, and a 1977 photograph of the couple wearing Shakespearean costumes hangs on a wall in Mrs. Whitley's home in Jamaica, Queens. It is from a production of ''Romeo and Juliet'' at the Teatro Nacional in Panama, the couple's native country.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Illness and Death of a Spouse Test a Family's Matriarch

docs.abstract: Children's Aid Society, which is supported by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, goes to aid of widow in Jamaica, Queens, who struggles with multiple sclerosis as she tries to keep her family together; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Angela Workman's goal for the near future is getting a record deal. Ms. Workman, who toured with Ray Charles as a Raelette background vocalist from 1985 through 1995, has since sung background vocals for Prince, George Clinton and Eminem and has already written the lyrics and recorded nine songs for ''Moonflowers,'' a pop-jazz project that she is producing with the keyboardist of the band Spyro Gyra. These activities, however, occupy only part of her life. For nearly four years, Ms. Workman has had a full-time day job as a receptionist at Tishman Speyer Properties, the Midtown real estate developer that is joint owner and manager of Rockefeller Center.

headline.main: The Artist's Perfect Day Job? It's the One Too Good to Quit

docs.abstract: Stereotype of frenzied aspiring artist jumping from one low-paying job to another between gigs is changing, as some artists have decided they want more balanced life that includes regular salary and medical benefits; one example is Angela Workman who toured with Ray Charles but works full-time for Tishman Speyer Properties, company that allows her time off to pursue her music; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Many artists, like Angela Workman, have decided they want a more balanced life -- one that includes a regular salary and medical benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Supreme Court turned down two last-minute moves yesterday to postpone Connecticut's execution of a convicted serial killer, clearing the way for the first execution in New England in 45 years, but it was delayed again this morning with little more than an hour to spare. Michael Bruce Ross had been scheduled to die at 2:01 a.m. today, but shortly before 1 a.m. state officials postponed the lethal injection until 9 p.m. Monday, after a question was raised about Mr. Ross's legal representation.

headline.main: Killer's Execution Is Delayed Despite Supreme Court Ruling

docs.abstract: US Supreme Court turns down two last-minute moves to postpone Connecticut's execution of convicted serial killer Michael Bruce Ross, clearing way for first execution in New England in 45 years, but it is delayed again after question is raised about his legal representation; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court turned down moves to postpone Connecticut's execution of a convicted serial killer. But state officials delayed the execution until Monday.

byline.original: By JAMES BARRON and STACEY STOWE; Julia Preston contributed reporting for this article
